Title: NA
comments: NA

Title: Folsom: New Archaeological Investigations of a Classic Paleoindian Bison Kill
comments: Assemblage is a mix of 1926-1927 CMNH, 1928 AMNH, and 1997-2002 SMU/QUEST excavations. Meltzer and Todd found marginal differences in element abundances between the excavations, but assessed that the overall integrity and representativeness of the assemblage was adequate for skeletal element analyses. Long bones were presented as complete, proximal, and distal specimens. Long bone element MNEs were calculated here as 'complete MNE' + 'proximal or distal MNE (whichever is most abundant)'. Carpal and tarsal MNE values here were obtained by taking the highest MNE values for each suite of carpal and tarsal MNE values reported in the analysis.

comments: Curation and excavation biases (especially regarding distal appendicular elements). Long bone MNE values were calculated using the whichever reported portion (proximal or distal) had the highest count. Carpal and tarsal MNE values were obtained from the suites of carpals and tarsal elements, with the element type in each category with the highest MNE value serving as the MNE here. Table 10.1 (pg 140).

Title: Buried Animal Kills and Processing Localities, Areas 1-5
Book/Journal: Murray Springs: A Clovis Site with Multiple Activity Areas in the San Pedro Valley, Arizona
Editors: C. Vance Haynes, Jr., Bruce B. Huckell
comments: Carpals and Tarsals published as undifferentiated counts (i.e., aggrgated across element types within each broad category). Hemmings indicates that, much like assumed here, an individual bson has 8 tarsal bones per individual (Table 5.3, pg 115). However, Hemmings also indicates that an individual bison has 8  carpal bones, wheres it is here treated as 12 per individual (i.e., 4 per side vs 6 per side; Table 5.3, pg 115). I assume that this is an error in Hemmings' Table 5.3, and treat the observed counts as across the six carpal types (i.e., 6 carpal types X 2 anatomical sides = 12 carpal bones per individual). Hemmings did not tabulate ribs and verts. Seasonalty information is from Wilson, Todd, and Frison (2007) [pp. 138-145, same volume]

Title: Bison Hunting at Cooper Site: Where Lightning Bolts Drew Thundering Herds
comments: Poorly dated, most dates are younger than Folsom age. Table 11 (pg 70). Both 'pelvis' and 'sacrum' are listed. It appears that 'pelvis' refers to an anatomical unit consisting of the reported sacra + portions of innominates that are otherwise unreported ('innominate' is not included as a category in Table 11). Since 'pelvis' and 'sacrum' are exclusive categories here (i.e., each component can only have counts in one or the other), I chose to include only the 'pelvis' counts.

Title: Archaeology of the Casper Site
Book/Journal: The Casper Site: A Hell Gap Bison Kill on the High Plains
comments: Seasonality estimate from Reher 1974 (same volume as main reference, pp. 113-124). MNE values were obtained by combining counts of elements in articulated units (Figures 1.32 and 1.33, pgs 65-66) with counts of disarticulated elements (Tables 1.1., 1.2, and 1.3. Pgs 67-69). For articulated unit figures, each segment was interpreted as one element, with the exception of mandibles, innominates, and phalanges. A line segment for 'Mandible' was interpreted as two mandibles articulated with a cranium. A line segment for '1st./2nd./3rd. Ph.' was interpreted as two phalanges for each articulated limb unit. A line segment for 'pelvis' was interpreted as two innominates for each articulated pelvic unit. For long bones, non-overlapping segments indicating proximal/distal portions were accounted for (i.e., only the portion with the greatest number of segments was included in MNE counts). For tarsals/carpals, the MNE for each unit was obtained by adding the most abundant carpal/tarsal from each anatomical side. For disarticulated cranial portions, MNE was obtained using the most abundant portion, accounting for side (i.e., 14 right petrous portions). For disarticulated ribs, counts of complete elements and proximal portions were added. For rib groups, counts were multiplied by the number of ribs in the group.For disarticulated innominates, os coxae counts were added to the largest counts of innominate bones on each side (left = ischium, right = ischium/pubis).

Title: (A) Summary of Skeletal Parts (B) X-Ray Densitometry Measurements of Bison Bone Mineral
comments: Seasonality estimates from Todd et al. 1997 (in same volume as main reference, pp. 145-176). pgs 225-227. Cranium MNE values uncertain as petrous portion MNEs are not provided for each side (since there are two petrous portions per cranium, the MNE of 16 could indicate anywhere from 8 to 16 for the cranium MNE). The sacrum MNE was obtained from Table 7.10 in Kreutzer's earlier chapter in the volume (pg 122), as it is missing in this table. The rib MNE in this appendix conflicts with the MNE in Table 7.10 (RI3 MNE = 125 in Table 7.10 vs RI2 MNE = 65 in the appendix). The value of 125 is used here.

Title: Paleoindian Bison Remains from the 12 Mile Creek Site in Western Kansas
comments: Old excavation, no reliable seasonality info (one fetal skeleton). Table 1 (pg 363). Long bone counts obtained by taking the highest MNE value provided across the distal and proximal portions. Carpals were presented as an undifferentiated aggregation of carpal element types. Tarsals were also listed in this manner, except for astragli and calcanea (MNE = 19 and 18, respectively). Given the high MNE of astragali, these were used here as the MNE for tarsal units. The low MNE listed for the aggregation of the remaining three tarsal element types (MNE = 32) indicates that there were probably fewer occurences of these tarsal types than there were occurences of astragli and calcanea. This is typical of archaeological bison assemblages--calcanea and astragali are often the most abundant tarsal type.

Sparse teeth and fetal remains were located throughout Zones I-III, but material was insufficient for a seasonality determination.

comments: Hill et al. indicate that the original excavators likely discarded much of the recovered faunal material. There is too little material from which to infer seasonality. Table 3 (pg 379). Numerous elements are not reported in Table 3, which may be because the original excavators discarded these elements. As such, they are scored here as NA rather than 0.

Title: Investigation of a 10,214 Year Old Late Plaoeindian Bison Kill at the Howard Gully Site in Southwestern Oklahoma
comments: No seasonality information is provided. Table 4 (pg 32). Given that the excavation was accomplished with modern collection standards, I assume that elements left unreported in Table 4 were not recovered during excavations.

Title: Collection Management and Analysis of the Lake Theo Folsom Bone Assemblage
comments: Curation and reporting issues. Seasonality info from Todd et al. 1996 (in: Frison GC, The Mill Iron Site, pp. 145-176. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque). "Scraps" not reported. Table 5.2 (pgs 88-93). Long bone MNEs obtained by adding the number of complete elements to the portion with the maximum MNE (proximal, distal, or shaft). Cranium MNE ignores a maxillary fragment and two condylar fragments. The 'rib' MNE included here ignores 69 rib specimens that are not adequately described, but are most likely blade fragments. The 'unspecifed vert' category here excludes epiphyseal specimens from MNE values. The 'innominate' category includes one specimen reported as 'pelvis' in Table 5.2. Buchana et al. 2015 (North American Archaeologist 36(3):170-196) also generated MNE values from this data. There are some discrepancies between the MNE values presented here and by Buchanan et al., but they are minor.

Title: The Archaeology and Taphonomy of the Heron Eden Site, Southwestern Saskatchewan
comments: Table 5.5 (pgs 103-104). Only elements in the paleosol included (no plow zone elements). Long bone MNEs obtained by taking the maximum value between proximal and distal portions. Table 5.5 presents sacrum MNEs as sacral verts. This value was divided by 5 to obtain the MNE for sacra presented here.

Authors: Kornfeld, Marcel, Mary L. Larson, Craign Arnold, Adam Wiewel, Mike Toft, Dennis Stanford
Title: The Nelson Site, a Cody Occupation in Northeastern Colorado
comments: Narrative states a winter season of death, although the dentitions in Table 5 span the fall and winter. The narrative seems to infer winter death based on the overlap between dentitions, assuming a single event (i.e., the overlap would be the inferred season). However, if representing more than one death event over a range of seasons, these dentitions might correspond to this range. Table 4 (pg 267). For long bone MNEs presented here, I used the largest values between proximal and distal portions presented in Table 4. Numerus elements are missing form the table (e.g., sacra and 3rd phalanges), but it is unclear if this is because they are missing from the assemblage or were not considered for analysis. As such, they are scored as NA here.

Authors: Johnson, Eileen and Vance T. Holliday
Title: Analysis of Paleoindian Bonebeds at the Clovis Site: New Data from Old Excavations
comments: Seasonality info in the reference is not secure enough for a seasonality assignment here. Numerous collection and curation biases, as well as unclear quantification units. Table 4 (pg 339). It is unclear if the specimens in Table 4 are non-overlapping within element categories (i.e., whether they can be treated as MNE values). Phalanx 2 and atlas are not listed in Table 4, but are assumed here to be zero since all other cervical verts and phalanges are listed. Other unlisted elements are left as NA, as it is unkown whether they were not collected, not analyzed, or are truely missing. MNE values were first generated for each animal carcass, then added togther across carcasses.

Title: The Jurgens Site
comments: Seasonality info from Hill and Hill 2002 (Current Research in the Pleistocene 19:104-106). They describe a "fall" event, although the dental age group of +0.4-0.5 is also consistent with the mid-late summer. Tables 1-4 (pgs 19, 20-22). Long bones in Tables 2-3 that are marked as "1/2" are counted here as whole elements. Since carpals and tarsals are aggregated in Table 1, the individual carpals and tarsals listed in Tables 2-3 were lumped into this. "Sacrum" in Table 4 is included under "Pelvis", as defined in Table 1. Lumbar and thoracic verts in Table 4 are lumped into "Unspecified verts" here, as that is how they are quantified in Table 1.

Title: The Jurgens Site
comments: Table 8 (pg 36). Most elements are fragments, and it is unlikely that the data in this table can be translated into MNE values. Only values for element categories not listed as fragments are included here. An exceptions was made for fragment counts of 1, which must logically correspond to an MNE of 1.

Title: The Jurgens Site
comments: Seasonality info from Hill and Hill 2002 (Current Research in the Pleistocene 19:104-106). They describe a "fall" event, although the dental age group of +0.4-0.5 is also consistent with the mid-late summer. Table 8 (pg 36). Table 10 and Tables 13-16 (pgs 43, 48-51). Long bones in Tables 13-14 that are marked as "1/2" are counted here as whole elements. Since carpals and tarsals are aggregated in Tables 10 and 15, the individual carpals and tarsals listed in Tables 13 and 14 were lumped into this. Axis, atlas, cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and caudal verts in Table 16 are lumped into "Unspecified verts" here, as that is how they are quantified in Table 10. Ribs are ignored here, as Table 10 lumps ribs and rib fragments together.

Title: The Olsen-Chubbuck Site: A Paleo-Indian Bison Kill
comments: Values added across Tables 1 and 3-15 (pgs 29, 32, 38, 40, 44, 47-48, 49, 52-55, 59-60, and 72). Caudal verts not counted, only reported as "present". Ribs reported as "present" in some tables, yet quantified in others. They are excluded here. Long bones mostly complete "1s", occassional "1/2s" counted as a complete long bone. Podials were excluded here, since the tabulation in the non-articulated units table makes it imposible to discern podial units.
